sen.j: 萬福寺（まんぷくじ）は、京都府宇治市にある黄檗宗（おうばくしゅう）大本山の寺院。
sen.e: Manpuku-ji Temple, located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture, is the grand head temple of the Obaku Sect of Buddhism.
Manpuku-ji Temple, located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture, is the grand head temple of the Obaku Sect of Buddhism.
Manpuku-ji Temple, located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture, is the grand head temple of the Obaku Sect of Buddhism.

sen.j: 山号は黄檗山、開山は隠元隆き（いんげんりゅうき）、本尊は釈迦如来である。
sen.e: It was founded by Yinyuan Longqi, has the honorific mountain prefix 'Obakusan' and is dedicated to the principal image Sakyamuni.
sen.cmt: ・Yinyuan Longqi: http://www.buddhistchannel.tv/index.php?id=44,6548,0,0,1,0・the principal image: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: It was founded by Yinyuan Longqi, has the honorific mountain prefix 'Obakusan' and is dedicated to the principal image Sakyamuni.
It was founded by Yinyuan Longqi, has the honorific mountain prefix 'Obakusan' and is dedicated to the principal image Shakamuni.

sen.j: 日本の近世以前の仏教各派の中では最も遅れて開宗した、黄檗宗の中心寺院で、中国・明出身の僧隠元を開山に請じて建てられた。
sen.e: It is the central temple of the Obaku Sect, the latest of the pre-modern Buddhist sects to be established in Japan, and was built after the Ming Dynasty Chinese monk, Yinyuan was invited to serve as Kaizan (first head priest).

It is the central temple of the Obaku Sect, the latest of the pre-modern Buddhist sects to be established in Japan, and was built after the Ming Dynasty Chinese monk, Yinyuan was invited to serve as Kaisan (first head priest).
sen.cmt: 開山→Kaisan Yahoo!辞書 大辞林 国語辞書その他より
sen.e: It is the central temple of the Obaku Sect, the latest of the pre-modern Buddhist sects to be established in Japan, and was built after the Ming Dynasty Chinese monk, Yinyuan was invited to serve as Kaisan (first head priest).

sen.j: 建物や仏像の様式、儀式作法から精進料理に至るまで中国風で、日本の一般的な仏教寺院とは異なった景観を有する。
sen.e: The temple is unique among Japan's Buddhist temples as it maintains a Chinese style from its buildings and Buddhist imagery to its ceremonies and vegetarian food.
The temple is unique among Japan's Buddhist temples as it maintains a Chinese style from its buildings and Buddhist imagery to its ceremonies and vegetarian food.
The temple is unique among Japan's Buddhist temples as it maintains a Chinese style from its buildings and Buddhist imagery to its ceremonies and vegetarian food.

sen.j: 「万福寺」と表記されることもあるが、宗教法人としての名称は「萬福寺」であるため、本項でも「萬福寺」と表記する。
sen.e: The 'Man' character of the temple's name 'Manpuki-ji' is sometimes written using the simplified kanji, but the temple's legal name uses the traditional kanji character.
The 'Man' character of the temple's name 'Manpuki-ji' is sometimes written using the simplified kanji (万), but the temple's legal name uses the traditional kanji character (萬).
sen.cmt: 原文の内容が分かりやすい様に、漢字を補足。必要無ければ省略して下さい。
sen.e: The 'Man' character of the temple's name 'Manpuki-ji' is sometimes written using the simplified kanji (万), but the temple's legal name uses the traditional kanji character (萬).

tit.e: The Obaku Sect and Japanese Culture
The Obaku Sect and Japanese Culture
The Obaku Sect and Japanese Culture

sen.j: 黄檗宗大本山である萬福寺の建築、仏像などは中国様式（明時代末期頃の様式）でつくられ、境内は日本の他の寺院とは異なった空間を形成している。
sen.e: The Obaku Sect's head temple, Manpuku-ji Temple has been built in a Chinese style (style of about the end of Ming dynasty) and the temple precinct is arranged differently to other Buddhist temples in Japan.

The Obaku Sect's head temple, Manpuku-ji Temple has been built in a Chinese style (style of about the end of Ming dynasty) and the temple precinct is arranged differently to other Buddhist temples in Japan.

The Obaku Sect's head temple, Manpuku-ji Temple houses Buddhist statues that are Chinese in style (the style that was prevalent around the end of the Ming dynasty) and the temple precinct is arranged differently to other Buddhist temples in Japan.
sen.cmt: 「仏像など」の部分の訳を補いました。

sen.j: 寺内で使われる言葉、儀式の作法なども中国式である。
sen.e: Even the words used within the temple and ritual conventions are Chinese.
Even the words used within the temple and ritual conventions are Chinese.
Even the words used within the temple and ritual conventions are in Chinese style.
sen.cmt: 中国式＝Chinese styleとしました。

sen.j: 本寺の精進料理は普茶料理と呼ばれる中国風のもので、植物油を多く使い、大皿に盛って取り分けて食べるのが特色である。
sen.e: The temple's Buddhist vegetarian food is a Chinese style cuisine known as Fucha, which characterized by the use large amounts of vegetable oil and being served on a large dish from which individual helpings are taken.

The temple's Buddhist vegetarian food is a Chinese style cuisine known as Fucha, which characterized by the use large amounts of vegetable oil and being served on a large dish from which individual helpings are taken.

The temple's Buddhist vegetarian food is a Chinese style cuisine known as Fucha, which is characterized by the use of large amounts of vegetable oil and being served on a large dish from which individual helpings are taken.
sen.cmt: “which characterized by the use large”=>”which is characterized by the use of large”

sen.j: 萬福寺は煎茶道の祖・売茶翁（ばいさおう）ゆかりの寺としても知られる。
sen.e: Manpuku-ji Temple is known for being closely related to green tea ceremony originator, Baisao.
Manpuku-ji Temple is known for being closely related to green tea ceremony originator, Baisao.
Manpuku-ji Temple is known for being closely related to green tea ceremony originator, Baisao.

sen.j: 隠元と弟子の木庵性トウ（もくあんしょうとう）、即非如一（そくひにょいつ）はいずれも書道の達人で、これら3名を「黄檗の三筆」と称する。
sen.e: Yinyuan's disciples Muyan Xingtao and Jifei Ruyi were both masters of calligraphy, and the three men are collectively referred to as 'Obaku no Sanpitsu' (The Three Master Calligraphers of the Obaku sect).

Yinyuan's disciples Muyan Xingtao and Jifei Ruyi were both masters of calligraphy, and the three men are collectively referred to as 'Obaku no Sanpitsu' (The Three Master Calligraphers of the Obaku sect).

Yinyuan and his disciples Muyan Xingtao and Jifei Ruyi were all masters of calligraphy, and the three men are collectively referred to as 'Obaku no Sanpitsu' (The Three Master Calligraphers of the Obaku sect).
sen.cmt: 主語に隠元自信も含めました。

sen.j: このように、隠元の来日と萬福寺の開創によって、新しい禅がもたらされただけでなく、さまざまな中国文化が日本にもたらされた。
sen.e: Therefore, Yingyuan's arrival in Japan and the founding of Manpuku-ji Temple brought not only new Zen Buddhism, but also various aspects of Chinese culture.
Therefore, Yinyuan's arrival in Japan and the founding of Manpuku-ji Temple brought not only new Zen Buddhism, but also various aspects of Chinese culture.
Therefore, Yinyuan's arrival in Japan and the founding of Manpuku-ji Temple brought not only new Zen Buddhism, but also various aspects of Chinese culture.

sen.j: 隠元の名に由来するインゲンマメのほか、孟宗竹（もうそうちく）、スイカ、レンコンなどをもたらしたのも隠元だといわれている。
sen.e: In addition to kidney beans ('ingenmame' in Japanese), which became named after Yingyuan, moso bamboo, watermelon and lotus root are also said to have been brought to Japan by Yingyuan.
sen.cmt: ・kidney bean: 新和英大辞典・watermelon: 新和英大辞典・lotus root: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: In addition to kidney beans ('ingenmame' in Japanese), which became named after Yinyuan, moso bamboo, watermelon and lotus root are also said to have been brought to Japan by Yinyuan.
In addition to kidney beans ('ingenmame' in Japanese), which became named after Yinyuan, moso bamboo, watermelon and lotus root are also said to have been brought to Japan by Yinyuan.

sen.j: 開山・隠元隆琦は中国明時代の万暦20年（1592年）、福建省福州市に生まれた。
sen.e: The temple's founding priest, Yinyuan Longqi was born in Ming Dynasty China's Fuzhou City, Fujian Province in 1592.
sen.cmt: ・Yinyuan Longqi: http://www.buddhistchannel.tv/index.php?id=44,6548,0,0,1,0・Fuzhou City, Fujian Province: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: The temple's founding priest, Yinyuan Longqi was born in Ming Dynasty China's Fuzhou City, Fujian Province in 1592.
The temple's founding priest, Yinyuan Longqi was born in Ming Dynasty China's Fuzhou City, Fujian Province in 1592.

sen.j: 29歳で仏門に入り、46歳の時、故郷の黄檗山萬福寺の住職となる。
sen.e: At age 29, he entered the Buddhist priesthood and, at age 46, served as chief priest at Wanfu Temple, Mount Huangbo, Fujian.
sen.cmt: ・entered the Buddhist priesthood: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: At age 29, he entered the Buddhist priesthood and, at age 46, served as chief priest at Wanfu Temple, Mount Huangbo, Fujian.
At age 29, he entered the Buddhist priesthood and, at age 46, served as chief priest at Wanfu Temple, Mount Huangbo, Fujian.

sen.j: 隠元は当時中国においても高名な僧で、その名声は日本にも届いていた。
sen.e: Yingyuan was a renowned monk in China at the time and his reputation reached as far as Japan.
Yinyuan was a renowned monk in China at the time and his reputation reached as far as Japan.
Yinyuan was a renowned monk in China at the time and his reputation reached as far as Japan.

sen.j: 隠元が招かれて来日するのは1654年（順治11年、承応3年）、63歳の時である。
sen.e: It was 1654 when Yingyuan was invited to Japan, aged 63.
It was 1654 when Yinyuan was invited to Japan, aged 63.
It was 1654 when Yinyuan was invited to Japan, aged 63.

sen.j: 当時の日本は鎖国政策を取り、海外との行き来は非常に限られていたが、長崎の港のみは開かれ、明人が居住し、崇福寺 (長崎市)（そうふくじ）、興福寺 (長崎市)のような唐寺（中国式の寺院）が建てられていた。
sen.e: At the time, Japan had adopted a policy of isolationism when travel into and out of Japan was highly restricted and only the port of Nagasaki was open, so those Ming Dynasty Chinese subjects in Japan constructed Chinese style temples such as Sofuku-ji Temple (Nagasaki City) and Kofuku-ji Temple (Nagasaki City).

At the time, Japan had adopted a policy of isolationism when travel into and out of Japan was highly restricted and only the port of Nagasaki was open, so those Ming Dynasty Chinese subjects in Japan constructed Chinese style temples such as Sofuku-ji Temple (Nagasaki City) and Kofuku-ji Temple (Nagasaki City).

At the time, Japan had adopted a policy of isolationism when travel into and out of Japan was highly restricted and only the port of Nagasaki was open, so those Ming Dynasty Chinese subjects in Japan constructed Chinese style temples such as Sofuku-ji Temple (Nagasaki City) and Kofuku-ji Temple (Nagasaki City).

sen.j: 隠元は長崎・興福寺の僧・逸然性融（いつねんしょうゆう）らの招きに応じて来日したものである。
sen.e: Yingyuan went to Japan after being invited by Monk Itsunen Shoyu of Kofuku-ji Temple in Nagasaki.
Yinyuan went to Japan after being invited by Monk Itsunen Shoyu of Kofuku-ji Temple in Nagasaki.
Yinyuan came to Japan after being invited by Monk Itsunen Shoyu of Kofuku-ji Temple in Nagasaki.
sen.cmt: 「来日」：went to Japan→ came to Japan

sen.j: はじめ、逸然が招いた僧は、隠元の弟子である也嬾性圭（やらんしょうけい）という僧であったが、也嬾の乗った船は遭難し、彼は帰らぬ人となってしまった。
sen.e: Itsunen originally invited Yingyuan's disciple, a monk named Yelan Xinggui, but he lost his life when the vessel on which he was travelling became lost at sea.
Itsunen originally invited Yinyuan's disciple, a monk named Yelan Xinggui, but he lost his life when the vessel on which he was travelling became lost at sea.
Itsunen originally invited Yinyuan's disciple, a monk named Yelan Xinggui, but he lost his life when the vessel on which he was traveling became lost at sea.

sen.j: そこで逸然は也嬾の師であり、日本でも名の知られていた隠元を招くこととした。
sen.e: This led Itsunen to invite Yelan's master, Yingyuan, who was also famous in Japan.
This led Itsunen to invite Yelan's master, Yinyuan, who was also famous in Japan.
This led Itsunen to invite Yelan's master, Yinyuan, who was also famous in Japan.

sen.j: 隠元は高齢を理由に最初は渡日を辞退したが、日本側からたびたび招請があり、また、志半ばで亡くなった弟子・也嬾性圭の遺志を果たしたいとの思いもあり、ついに渡日を決意する。
sen.e: Yingyuan initially declined to travel to Japan due to his age, but finally decided to make the trip after frequent invitations and the desire to fulfill the dying wish of his disciple Yelan Xinggui who passed away without realizing his ambition.

Yinyuan initially declined to travel to Japan due to his age, but finally decided to make the trip after frequent invitations and the desire to fulfill the dying wish of his disciple Yelan Xinggui who passed away without realizing his ambition.

Yinyuan initially declined to travel to Japan due to his age, but finally decided to make the trip after frequent invitations and the desire to fulfill the dying wish of his disciple Yelan Xinggui who passed away without realizing his ambition.

sen.j: 承応3年（1654年）、30名の弟子とともに来日した隠元は、はじめ長崎の興福寺、次いで摂津富田（せっつとんだ、現・大阪府高槻市）の普門寺（ふもんじ）に住した。
sen.e: In 1654, Yingyuan travelled to Japan with 30 disciples, first residing at Nagasaki's Kofuku-ji Temple and then Fumon-ji Temple in Settsutonda (present day Takatsuki City, Osaka Prefecture).
In 1654, Yinyuan travelled to Japan with 30 disciples, first residing at Nagasaki's Kofuku-ji Temple and then Fumon-ji Temple in Settsutonda (present day Takatsuki City, Osaka Prefecture).
In 1654, Yinyuan traveled to Japan with 30 disciples, first residing at Nagasaki's Kofuku-ji Temple and then Fumon-ji Temple in Settsutonda (present day Takatsuki City, Osaka Prefecture).

sen.j: 隠元は中国に残してきた弟子たちには「3年後には帰国する」という約束をしていた。
sen.e: Yingyuan promised the disciples left in China that he would return in 3 years.
Yinyuan promised the disciples left in China that he would return in 3 years.
Yinyuan promised the disciples left in China that he would return in 3 years.

sen.j: 来日3年目になると、中国の弟子や支援者たちから隠元の帰国を要請する手紙が多数届き、隠元本人も帰国を希望したが、元妙心寺住持の龍渓性潜（りょうけいしょうせん）をはじめとする日本側の信奉者たちは、隠元が日本に留まることを強く希望し、その旨を幕府にも働きかけている。
sen.e: When the three years were up, he received numerous letters from his disciples and supporters in China requesting his return and he also wanted to return but many of his devotees in Japan, including former chief priest of Myosin-ji Temple, Ryokei Shosen, firmly hoped that he remain in Japan and appealed to the Shogunate.

When the three years were up, he received numerous letters from his disciples and supporters in China requesting his return and he also wanted to return but many of his devotees in Japan, including former chief priest of Myosin-ji Temple, Ryokei Shosen, firmly hoped that he remain in Japan and appealed to the Shogunate.

When the three years were up, he received numerous letters from his disciples and supporters in China requesting his return and he also wanted to return but many of his devotees in Japan, including former chief priest of Myosin-ji Temple, Ryokei Shosen, firmly hoped that he remain in Japan and appealed to the Shogunate.

sen.j: 万治元年（1658年）、隠元は江戸へおもむき、将軍徳川家綱に拝謁している。
sen.e: In 1658, Yingyuan headed to Edo for an audience with Shogun Ietsuna TOKUGAWA.
In 1658, Yinyuan headed to Edo for an audience with Shogun Ietsuna TOKUGAWA.
In 1658, Yinyuan headed to Edo for an audience with Shogun Ietsuna TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 家綱も隠元に帰依し、翌万治3年（1660年）には幕府によって山城国宇治に土地が与えられ、隠元のために新しい寺が建てられることになった。
sen.e: Ietsuna also became devoted to Yingyuan and, in the following year in 1660, the Shogunate granted him land in Uji, Yamashiro Provence on which a new temple for was built for him.
Ietsuna also became devoted to Yinyuan and, in the following year in 1660, the Shogunate granted him land in Uji, Yamashiro Province on which a new temple for was built for him.
Ietsuna also became devoted to Yinyuan and, in the following year in 1660, the Shogunate granted him land in Uji, Yamashiro Province on which a new temple for was built for him.

sen.j: ここに至って隠元も日本に留まることを決意し、当初3年間の滞在で帰国するはずであったのが、結局日本に骨を埋めることとなった。
sen.e: Yingyuan had now decided to remain in Japan and, although he was originally to return to China after only three years, he ended up being buried in Japan.
Yinyuan had now decided to remain in Japan and, although he was originally to return to China after only three years, he ended up being buried in Japan.
Yinyuan had now decided to remain in Japan and, although he was originally to return to China after only three years, he ended up being buried in Japan.

sen.j: 寺は故郷福州の寺と同名の黄檗山萬福寺と名付けられ、寛文元年（1661年）に開創され、造営工事は将軍や諸大名の援助を受けて延宝7年（1679年）頃にほぼ完成した。
sen.e: The temple, founded in 1661, was given the same name as the one in his home in Fuzhou, which, in Japanese is pronounced Obakusan Manfuku-ji and construction proceeded with the support of the Shogun and several Daimyo so that the temple was essentially complete by 1679.

The temple, founded in 1661, was given the same name as the one in his home in Fuzhou, which, in Japanese is pronounced Obakusan Manfuku-ji and construction proceeded with the support of the Shogun and several Daimyo so that the temple was essentially complete by 1679.

The temple, founded in 1661, was given the same name as the one in his home in Fuzhou, which, in Japanese is pronounced Obakusan Manfuku-ji and construction proceeded with the support of the Shogun and several Daimyo so that the temple was essentially complete by 1679.

tit.cmt: 伽藍の読みもいれました。

sen.j: 伽藍は西を正面とし、左右相称に整然と配置されている。
sen.e: The front of the temple faces West and the buildings are arranged in a neat, symmetrical layout.
The front of the temple faces West and the buildings are arranged in a neat, symmetrical layout.
The front of the Garan faces West and the buildings are arranged in a neat, symmetrical layout.

sen.j: 総門をくぐると右手に放生池、その先に三門があり、三門の正面には天王殿、その奥に大雄宝殿（だいおうほうでん）、さらに奥に法堂（はっとう）が西から東へ一直線に並ぶ。
sen.e: Entering through the main gate and walking in a straight line from west to east, Hojo-ike pond is to the right, the Sanmon gate stands further on, directly through this is the Tenno-den hall, further along is the Daiyuu Ho-den hall, and past this is the Hatto.

Entering through the main gate and walking in a straight line from west to east, Hojo-ike pond is to the right, the Sammon gate stands further on, directly through this is the Tenno-den hall, further along is the Daio Ho-den hall, and past this is the Hatto.

Entering through the main gate and walking in a straight line from west to east, Hojo-ike pond is to the right, the Sammon gate stands further on, directly through this is the Tenno-den hall, further along is the Daio Ho-den hall, and past this is the Hatto.

sen.j: これら諸堂の間は回廊で結ばれている。
sen.e: These halls are connected by roofed walkways.
These halls are connected by roofed walkways.
These halls are connected by roofed walkways.

sen.j: 天王殿と大雄宝殿の間をロの字状に結ぶ回廊に沿って右側（南側）には鐘楼、伽藍堂、斎堂があり、左側（北側）には対称的な位置に鼓楼、祖師堂、禅堂が建つ。
sen.e: The square walkway connecting the Tenno-den and Daiyuu Ho-den hall is lined on the right side (southern side) by the belfry, Garan-do hall and Sai-do hall, and on the left side (northern side) lined by the drum tower, Shiso-do hall and Zen-do hall in symmetrical positions.

The square walkway connecting the Tenno-den and Daio Ho-den hall is lined on the right side (southern side) by the Belfry, Garan-do hall and Sai-do hall, and on the left side (northern side) lined by the Drum tower, Soshi-do hall and Zen-do hall in symmetrical positions.

The square walkway connecting the Tenno-den and Daio Ho-den hall is lined on the right side (southern side) by the Belfry, Garan-do hall and Sai-do hall, and on the left side (northern side) lined by the Drum tower, Soshi-do hall and Zen-do hall in symmetrical positions.

sen.j: これらの建物は日本の一般的な寺院建築とは異なり、中国の明時代末期頃の様式でつくられ、材料も南方産のチーク材が使われている。
sen.e: These buildings differ from usual Japanese temple architecture in that they have been built in a late Ming Dynasty Chinese style and constructed from southern teatwood.
sen.cmt: ・temple architecture: 新和英大辞典・teakwood: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: These buildings differ from usual Japanese temple architecture in that they have been built in a late Ming Dynasty Chinese style and constructed from southern teakwood.
These buildings differ from usual Japanese temple architecture in that they have been built in a late Ming Dynasty Chinese style and constructed from southern teakwood.

sen.j: 「卍字くずし」のデザインによる高欄、「黄檗天井」と呼ばれるアーチ形の天井、円形の窓、扉に彫られた「桃符」と呼ばれる桃の実形の飾りなど、日本の他の寺院ではあまり見かけないデザインや技法が多用されている。
sen.e: Numerous designs and techniques rarely seen in Japan have been incorporated, including balustrades with a decorative swastika patterns, arched ceilings named 'Obaku ceilings', circular windows and a decorative peach shape named 'To-fu' engraved on the doors.

Numerous designs and techniques rarely seen in Japan have been incorporated, including balustrades with 'Manji-Kuzushi,' decorative swastika' patterns, arched ceilings named 'Obaku ceilings', circular windows and a decorative peach shape named 'To-fu' engraved on the doors.

Numerous designs and techniques rarely seen in Japan have been incorporated, including balustrades with 'Manji-Kuzushi,' decorative swastika' patterns, arched ceilings named 'Obaku ceilings', circular windows and a decorative peach shape named 'To-fu' engraved on the doors.

sen.j: これらのほか、三門 - 天王殿間の参道を左（北）に折れたところに開山の塔所である松隠堂と呼ばれる一画があり、開山堂、舎利殿などが建つ。
sen.e: In addition, taking a left (north) from the path between the Sanmon gate and Tenno-den leads to an area named Shoin-do hall that is dedicated to the temple founder, in which buildings including the Kaizan-do hall and reliquary hall stand.

In addition, taking a left (north) from the path between the Sammon gate and Tenno-den leads to an area named Shoin-do hall that is dedicated to the temple founder, in which buildings including the Kaisan-do hall and reliquary hall stand.

In addition, taking a left (north) from the path between the Sammon gate and Tenno-den leads to an area named Shoin-do hall that is dedicated to the temple founder, in which buildings including the Kaisan-do hall and reliquary hall stand.

sen.j: 総門 - 寛文元年（1661年）の建立。
sen.e: Main gate: Constructed in 1661.
Main gate: Constructed in 1661.
Main gate: Constructed in 1661.

sen.j: 瓦屋根の中央部分を高く、左右の部分を低く、段差を設けているのは中国風で、日本の一般的な社寺建築には見かけない形式である。
sen.e: This multilevel design Chinese style gate with a tiled roof that is high in the middle but low on the left and right sides has a form that is not generally seen in Japanese shrine and temple architecture.

This multilevel design Chinese style gate with a tiled roof that is high in the middle but low on the left and right sides has a form that is not generally seen in Japanese shrine and temple architecture.

This multilevel design Chinese style gate with a tiled roof that is high in the middle but low on the left and right sides has a form that is not generally seen in Japanese shrine and temple architecture.

sen.j: 屋根上左右に乗る魚のようなものは鯱ではなく、摩伽羅という想像上の生物でヒレの代わりに足が生えている。
sen.e: The fish on the left and right of the roof are not orcas but fictional creatures called makara that have legs instead of fins.
The fish on the left and right of the roof are not orcas but fictional creatures called makara that have legs instead of fins.
The fish on the left and right of the roof are not orcas but fictional creatures called Makara that have legs instead of fins.

sen.j: マカラはサンスクリット及びパーリ語でワニを表す言葉で、東南アジアでは仏教寺院の入口などに用いられている。
sen.e: The word 'makara' means crocodile in the Sanskrit and Pali languages and is used on the entrances of Buddhist temples in southeast Asia.
The word 'makara' means crocodile in the Sanskrit and Pali languages and is used on the entrances of Buddhist temples in southeast Asia.
The word 'Makara' means crocodile in the Sanskrit and Pali languages and is used on the entrances of Buddhist temples in southeast Asia.

sen.j: 三門 - 延宝6年（1678年）の建立。
sen.e: Sanmon gate: Constructed in 1678.
Sammon gate: Constructed in 1678.
Sammon gate: Constructed in 1678.

sen.j: 三間三戸二重門である。
sen.e: It is two-storey gate with three bays and two entrances.
It is two-storey gate with three bays and three entrances.
It is two-storey gate with three bays and three entrances.

sen.j: 「三間三戸」は門の正面柱間が3間で、3間すべてが通路になっているものを指す（日本の禅宗寺院の三門は一般的には「五間三戸」である）。
sen.e: Three bays and two entrances' means that all three of the front bays serve as entrances (Japanese Zen Buddhist temples usually have a Sanmon gate with five bays and three entrances).
Three bays and three entrances' means that all three of the front bays serve as entrances (Japanese Zen Buddhist temples usually have a Sammon gate with 'five bays and three entrances').
Three bays and three entrances' means that all three of the front bays serve as entrances (Japanese Zen Buddhist temples usually have a Sammon gate with 'five bays and three entrances').

sen.j: 天王殿 - 寛文8年（1668年）の建立。
sen.e: Tenno-den: Constructed in 1668.
Tenno-den: Constructed in 1668.
Tenno-den: Constructed in 1668.

sen.j: 一重入母屋造。
sen.e: A single-storey hip-and-gable roof structure.
A single-storey hip-and-gable roof structure.
A single-storey hip-and-gable roof structure.

sen.j: 本堂の手前にこのような堂を置くのは中国式の伽藍配置で、日本では珍しい。
sen.e: The placement of a hall such as this directly in front of the main hall is a feature of the Chinese style temple layout that is rarely found in Japan.
The placement of a hall such as this directly in front of the main hall is a feature of the Chinese style temple layout that is rarely found in Japan.
The placement of a hall such as this directly in front of the main hall is a feature of the Chinese style temple layout that is rarely found in Japan.

sen.j: 内部には弥勒菩薩の化身とされる布袋尊像を安置する。
sen.e: Within is housed a statue of Hotei, who is believed to have been an incarnation of Maitreya.
sen.cmt: ・incarnation: 新和英大辞典・Maitreya: 新和英大辞典
sen.e: Within is housed a statue of Hotei, who is believed to have been an incarnation of Maitreya.
Within is housed a statue of Hotei, who is believed to have been an incarnation of Maitreya.

sen.j: この像は日本で著名な半跏思惟形の弥勒菩薩像とは全く異なり、太鼓腹の布袋像として表わされている。
sen.e: This statue is completely different from the statue of Maitreya sitting contemplatively in the half-lotus position that is well-known in Japan and instead presents the form of a potbellied Hotei.
This statue is completely different from the statue of Maitreya sitting contemplatively in the half-lotus position that is well-known in Japan and instead presents the form of a potbellied Hotei.
This statue is completely different from the statue of Maitreya sitting contemplatively in the half-lotus position that is well-known in Japan and instead presents the form of a potbellied Hotei.

sen.j: 他に堂内左右に四天王像、布袋像の背後に韋駄天像を安置する。
sen.e: The hall also houses a statue of Skanda, which sits behind the left and right statues of the four heavenly kings and Hotei.
The hall also houses a statue of Skanda, which sits behind Hotei, and statues of the four heavenly kings on both sides of it.
sen.cmt: 韋駄天像は布袋像の後ろ、四天王像は堂内の左右にある。
sen.e: The hall also houses a statue of Skanda, which sits behind Hotei, and statues of the four heavenly kings on both sides of it.

sen.j: これらの像は来日していた明の仏師・范道生の作で、いずれも中国風の様式でつくられている。
sen.e: These are all Chinese style statues that were created by the Ming Dynasty Chinese Buddhist sculptor Daosheng FAN who travelled to Japan.
These are all Chinese style statues that were created by the Ming Dynasty Chinese Buddhist sculptor Daosheng FAN who travelled to Japan.
These are all Chinese style statues that were created by the Ming Dynasty Chinese Buddhist sculptor Daosheng FAN who traveled to Japan.

sen.j: 大雄宝殿-寛文8年（1668年）の建立。
sen.e: Daiyuu Ho-den hall: Constructed in 1668.
Daio Ho-den hall: Constructed in 1668.
sen.cmt: 前述より、だいおうほうでん。
sen.e: Daio Ho-den hall: Constructed in 1668.

sen.j: 日本の一般的な寺院の「本堂」「仏殿」にあたる建物である。
sen.e: Equivalent to the 'main hall' or 'Buddha hall' of conventional Japanese Buddhist temples.
Equivalent to the 'main hall' or 'Buddha hall' of conventional Japanese Buddhist temples.
Equivalent to the 'main hall' or 'Buddha hall' of conventional Japanese Buddhist temples.

sen.j: 入母屋造。
sen.e: It is a hip-and-gable roof structure.
It is a hip-and-gable roof structure.
It is a hip-and-gable roof structure.

sen.j: 2階建てに見えるが一重裳階（もこし）付きである。
sen.e: It appears to have two stories but is in fact one storey with a pent roof enclosure.
It appears to have two stories but is in fact one storey with a pent roof enclosure.
It appears to have two stories but is in fact one story with a pent roof enclosure.
sen.cmt: “storey” は英国英語で、一般には“story”が使われている。

sen.j: 本尊釈迦三尊像（脇侍は阿難と迦葉）、十八羅漢像を安置する。
sen.e: It houses a statue of Gautama Buddha flanked by two attendants (Ananda and Kasyapa) and statues of the 18 arhats.
It houses a statue of Gautama Buddha flanked by two attendants (Ananda and Kasyapa) and statues of the 18 arhats.
It houses a statue of Gautama Buddha flanked by two attendants (Ananda and Kasyapa) and statues of the 18 arhats.

sen.j: 建物の前には白砂を敷いた「月台」がある。
sen.e: A podium covered with sand, called 'getsudai', stands in front of the building.
A podium covered with sand, called 'getsudai', stands in front of the building.
A podium covered with sand, called 'getsudai', stands in front of the building.

sen.j: 法堂 - 寛文2年（1662年）の建立。
sen.e: Hatto: Constructed in 1662.
Hatto: Constructed in 1662.
Hatto: Constructed in 1662.

sen.j: 一重入母屋造。
sen.e: A single-storey hip-and-gable roof structure.
A single-storey hip-and-gable roof structure.
A single-storey hip-and-gable roof structure.

sen.j: 鐘楼 - 2階建てで、階上に梵鐘を吊る。
sen.e: Belfry: A two storey structure with a bell suspended in the upper storey.
Belfry: A two storey structure with a bell suspended in the upper storey.
Belfry: A two storey structure with a bell suspended in the upper storey.

sen.j: 鐘楼前には偈（げ）の書かれた巡照板が下げられている。
sen.e: A junsho-ban with a gatha poem written on it is suspended in front of the belfry.
A junsho-ban with a gatha poem written on it is suspended in front of the Belfry.
A junsho-ban with a gatha poem written on it is suspended in front of the Belfry.

sen.j: 伽藍堂 - 関聖大帝菩薩（関羽）を安置する。
sen.e: Garan-do hall: Houses Guansheng Dadi Pusa (Guan Yu).
Garan-do hall: Houses Guansheng Dadi Pusa (Guan Yu).
Garan-do hall: Houses Guansheng Dadi Pusa (Guan Yu).

sen.j: 斎堂 - 食堂であり、緊那羅王像を安置する。
sen.e: Sai-do hall: The dining hall houses a statue of Kinnarao.
Sai-do hall: The dining hall houses a statue of Kinnarao.
Sai-do hall: The dining hall houses a statue of Kinnarao.

sen.j: 斎堂前には開梆（かいぱん、「ぱん」は木偏に邦）という巨大な木製の魚が吊り下げられている。
sen.e: A large wooden fish named 'Kaipan' hangs from the front of Sai-do hall.
A large wooden fish named 'Kaipan' hangs from the front of Sai-do hall.
A large wooden fish named 'Kaipan' hangs from the front of Sai-do hall.

sen.j: これは叩いて食事や法要の時間を知らせるためのものであり、木魚の原型と言われている。
sen.e: It is struck to signal when it is time for meals or services and is said to be where fish-shaped wooden temple drums originated.
It is struck to signal when it is time for meals or services and is said to be where fish-shaped wooden temple drums originated.
It is struck to signal when it is time for meals or services and is said to be where fish-shaped wooden temple drums originated.

sen.j: 開版、魚梆、飯梆などとも書く。
sen.e: The word 'kaipan' is written using various combinations of kanji characters.
The word 'kaipan' is written using various combinations of kanji characters.
The word 'kaipan' is written using various combinations of kanji characters.

sen.j: 鼓楼 - 鐘楼と対称位置に建ち、階上に太鼓を置く。
sen.e: Drum tower: Stands on a site symmetrical to the belfry and has a drum suspended in the upper part.
Drum tower: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Belfry and has a drum suspended in the upper part.
Drum tower: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Belfry and has a drum suspended in the upper part.

sen.j: 祖師堂 - 伽藍堂と対称位置に建ち、中国禅宗の祖である達磨の像と歴代住職の位牌を安置する。
sen.e: Shiso-do hall: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Garan-do hall and houses the memorial tablets of the father of Chinese Zen Buddhism, Bodhidharma as well as successive head priests.
Soshi-do hall: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Garan-do hall and houses the memorial tablets of the father of Chinese Zen Buddhism, Bodhidharma as well as successive head priests.
Soshi-do hall: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Garan-do hall and houses the memorial tablets of the father of Chinese Zen Buddhism, Bodhidharma as well as successive head priests.

sen.j: 禅堂 - 斎堂と対称位置に建つ。
sen.e: Zen-do hall: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Sai-do hall.
Zen-do hall: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Sai-do hall.
Zen-do hall: Stands on a site symmetrical to the Sai-do hall.

sen.j: 坐禅堂である。
sen.e: It is a Zen meditation hall.
It is a Zen meditation hall.
It is a Zen meditation hall.

sen.j: 威徳殿 - 法堂の裏、一段高い位置に建ち、徳川歴代将軍を祀る。
sen.e: Itoku-den hall: Stands on higher ground at the back of the Hatto and enshrines successive Tokugawa Shogun.
Itoku-den hall: Stands on higher ground at the back of the Hatto and enshrines successive Tokugawa Shogun.
Itoku-den hall: Stands on higher ground at the back of the Hatto and enshrines successive Tokugawa Shogun.

sen.j: 一般には公開していない。
sen.e: Not ordinarily open to the public.
Not ordinarily open to the public.
Not ordinarily open to the public.

sen.j: 他に、東方丈、西方丈、黄龍閣（大庫裏）、慈光堂（祀堂）が重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: In addition, the Tohojo, Seihojo, Oryokaku (Ookuri) and vJikodo (Shido) have all been designated Important Cultural Properties.
In addition, the Tohojo, Seihojo, Oryokaku (Okuri) and Jikodo (Shido) have all been designated Important Cultural Properties.
In addition, the Tohojo, Seihojo, Oryokaku (Okuri) and Jikodo (Shido) have all been designated Important Cultural Properties.

sen.j: 指定外の建物としては売茶翁を祭る売茶堂などがある。
sen.e: Non-listed buildings include Baisa-do, which is dedicated to Baisao.
Non-listed buildings include Baisa-do, which is dedicated to Baisao.
Non-listed buildings include Baisa-do, which is dedicated to Baisao.

sen.j: 松隠堂 - 三門をくぐった参道の左側（北側）の一郭。
sen.e: Shoin-do hall: An enclosure at the end of the path that leads left after passing through the Sanmon gate.
Shoin-do hall: An enclosure at the end of the path that leads left (north) after passing through the Sammon gate.
Shoin-do hall: An enclosure at the end of the path that leads left (north) after passing through the Sammon gate.

sen.j: 開山堂、舎利殿、客殿などの建物が建つ。
sen.e: Includes the Kaizan-do hall, reliquery hall and Kyaku-den hall (guest hall).
Includes the Kaisan-do hall, reliquary hall and Kyaku-den hall (guest hall).
Includes the Kaisan-do hall, reliquary hall and Kyaku-den hall (guest hall).

sen.j: 隠元が2世の木庵に住職を譲った後の隠居所として居住したところである。
sen.e: It is where Yingyuan lived during his retirement after passing on the position of head priest to Muyan.
It is where Yinyuan lived during his retirement after passing on the position of head priest to Muyan.
It is where Yinyuan lived during his retirement after passing on the position of head priest to Muyan.

sen.j: 寛文3年（1663年）、隠元に帰依するある夫人から屋敷を寄付され、萬福寺に移築して「松隠堂」と称したことに始まる。
sen.e: An estate was donated in 1663 by a nobleman's wife who was devoted to Yinguyan and renamed 'Shoin-do' after being relocated to Manpuku-ji Temple.
An estate was donated in 1663 by a nobleman's wife who was devoted to Yinuyan and renamed 'Shoin-do' after being relocated to Manpuku-ji Temple.
An estate was donated in 1663 by a nobleman's wife who was devoted to Yinuyan and renamed 'Shoin-do' after being relocated to Manpuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 隠元の死後は開山塔院（墓所）となっている。
sen.e: It became a Kaizan To-in (burial ground) after Yingyuan's death.
It became a Kaizan To-in (burial ground) after Yinyuan's death.
It became a Kaizan To-in (burial ground) after Yinyuan's death.

sen.j: 松隠堂は元は萬福寺とは独立した宗教法人であったが、昭和34年（1959年）に宗教法人萬福寺と合併した。
sen.e: Shoin-do hall was originally an independent religious corporation but merged with the Manpuku-ji Temple religious corporation in 1959.
Shoin-do hall was originally an independent religious corporation but merged with the Manpuku-ji Temple religious corporation in 1959.
Shoin-do hall was originally an independent religious corporation but merged with the Manpuku-ji Temple religious corporation in 1959.

sen.j: 文華殿 - 三門をくぐって右手にある宝物館。
sen.e: Bunka-den hall: Stands on the right after passing through the Sanmon gate.
Bunka-den hall: A treasure hall that stands on the right after passing through the Sammon gate.
sen.cmt: treasure hallを補足。 Sammonを補足。
sen.e: Bunka-den hall: A treasure hall that stands on the right after passing through the Sammon gate.

sen.j: 宗祖三百回忌を機に昭和47年（1972年）に建てられたもので、展示室のほか、黄檗文化研究所を設置する。
sen.e: The building was constructed in 1972 on the 300th anniversary of the death of the sect's founder and serves as an exhibition room as well as an Obaku Cultural Research Institute.
The building was constructed in 1972 on the 300th anniversary of the death of the sect's founder and serves as an exhibition room as well as an Obaku Cultural Research Institute.
The building was constructed in 1972 on the 300th anniversary of the death of the sect's founder and serves as an exhibition room as well as an Obaku Cultural Research Institute.

sen.j: 「萬福寺」16棟（総門、三門、天王殿、大雄宝殿、法堂、鐘楼、鼓楼、伽藍堂、祖師堂、斎堂、禅堂、東方丈、西方丈、祠堂、大庫裏、威徳殿）（附廊8棟、鎮守社、廊棟札、伽藍絵図5点、作事関係文書7冊）
sen.e: 16 buildings of Manpuku-ji Temple (main gate, Sanmon gate, Tenno-den hall, Daiyuu Ho-den hall, Hatto, belfry, drum tower, Garan-do hall, Shiso-do hall, Sai-do hall, Tohojo, Saihojo, Shi-do hall, Okuri, Itoku-den hall) (including 8 corridors, Shinto shrine, Ro Munefuda, 5 paintings of the temple, 7 books relating to the temple's construction).

16 buildings of Manpuku-ji Temple (main gate, Sammon gate, Tenno-den hall, Daio Ho-den hall, Hatto, Belfry, Drum tower, Garan-do hall, Soshi-do hall, Sai-do hall, Zen-do hall, Tohojo, Saihojo, Shi-do hall, Okuri, Itoku-den hall) (including 8 corridors, Tutelary shrine, Ro Munefuda, 5 paintings of the temple, 7 books relating to the temple's construction).
sen.cmt: Sanmon→SammonDaiyuu→Daio Belfry, Drumに訂正。Shiso→Soshi Zen-do hallを補足。鎮守社→Tutelary shrine
sen.e: 16 buildings of Manpuku-ji Temple (main gate, Sammon gate, Tenno-den hall, Daio Ho-den hall, Hatto, Belfry, Drum tower, Garan-do hall, Soshi-do hall, Sai-do hall, Zen-do hall, Tohojo, Seihojo, Shi-do hall, Okuri, Itoku-den hall) (including 8 corridors, Tutelary shrine, Ro Munefuda, 5 paintings of the temple, 7 books relating to the temple's construction).

sen.j: 「萬福寺松隠堂」7棟（通玄門、開山堂、舎利殿、寿蔵、客殿、庫裏、侍真寮）（附裏門、宝蔵、鐘楼、廊2棟、石碑亭）
sen.e: 7 buildings of Manpuku-ji Temple Shoin-do (Tsugen-mon gate, Kaizan-do hall, reliquery hall, Juzo, Kyaku-den, Kuri, Jishinryo (including the rear gate, Hozo, belfry, 2 corridors, Sekihi-tei)
7 buildings of Manpuku-ji Temple Shoin-do (Tsugen-mon gate, Kaisan-do hall, reliquary hall, Juzo, Kyaku-den, Kuri, Jishinryo (including the rear gate, Hozo, Belfry, 2 corridors, Sekihi-tei)
7 buildings of Manpuku-ji Temple Shoin-do (Tsugen-mon gate, Kaisan-do hall, reliquary hall, Juzo, Kyaku-den, Kuri, Jishinryo (including the rear gate, Hozo, Belfry, 2 corridors, Sekihi-tei)

tit.j: 重要文化財（美術工芸品）

sen.j: 紙本淡彩西湖図4幅、西湖図4幅、虎渓三笑図8幅、五百羅漢図8幅、瀑布図4枚、波涛図1面 池大雅筆
sen.e: 4 Shihon-Tansai Saiko-zu, 4 Saiko-zu, 8 Kokeisansho-zu, 8 Gohyakurakan-zu, 4 Bakufu-zu and 1 Hato-zu all painted by Taiga IKENO.
4 Shihon-Tansai Saiko-zu, 4 Saiko-zu, 8 Kokeisansho-zu, 8 Gohyakurakan-zu, 4 Bakufu-zu and 1 Hato-zu all painted by Taiga IKENO.
4 Shihon-Tansai Saiko-zu, 4 Saiko-zu, 8 Kokeisansho-zu, 8 Gohyakurakan-zu, 4 Bakufu-zu and 1 Hato-zu all painted by IKE no Taiga.

sen.j: 紙本著色隠元和尚像 元規筆 隠元自題あり
sen.e: Color on paper portrait of Priest Yingyuan painted by Genki with Ingen's own title
Color on paper portrait of Priest Yinyuan painted by Genki with Yinyuan's own title
sen.cmt: Yingyuan→Yinyuan他セルでも隠元は全て中国語表記になっているので統一。Ingen's→Yinyuan's
sen.e: Color on paper portrait of Priest Yinyuan painted by Genki with Yinyuan's own title

sen.j: 絖本淡彩観音図 1帖（18図） 陳賢筆 崇禎九年の款記、隠元の題字及び賛がある
sen.e: Book of light color on shiny silk images of Kannon (18 images) painted by Xian CHEN dated 1635 with the title and inscriptions of Kuanji and Yingyuan
Book of light color on shiny silk images of Kannon (18 images) painted by Xian CHEN dated 1636 with the title and inscription of Yinyuan
sen.cmt: 崇禎九年→1636 Kuanjiを削除。 Yingyuan→Yinyuan
sen.e: Book of light color on shiny silk images of Kannon (18 images) painted by Xian CHEN dated 1636 with the title and inscription of Yinyuan

sen.j: 黄檗山木額・柱聯（ちゅうれん）・榜牌（ぼうはい）（額40面、聯44対、榜牌13面、下書14幅）
sen.e: Obakuzan wooden frame/pillar couplet/board (40 frames, 44 couplets, 3 boards, 14 manuscripts)
Obakuzan wooden frame/pillar couplet/board (40 frames, 44 couplets, 13 boards, 14 manuscripts)
Obakuzan wooden frame/pillar couplet/board (40 frames, 44 couplets, 13 boards, 14 manuscripts)

sen.j: 一般人の座禅などの修行体験を受け付けている（公式サイト参照）。
sen.e: Training ascetic practices such as Zen meditation are on offer to the general public (see official website).
Training ascetic practices such as Zen meditation are on offer to the general public (see official website).
Training ascetic practices such as Zen meditation are on offer to the general public (see official website).

sen.j: ユニークなのがレース中に違反行為を重ねた競輪選手のペナルティ（「特別指導訓練」と称する）として使われること。
sen.e: It is unique in that it is used as a penalty (special instruction training) for professional cyclists who have repeatedly violated the rules during races.
It is unique in that it is used as a penalty (special instruction training) for professional cyclists who have repeatedly violated the rules during races.
It is unique in that it is used as a penalty (special instruction training) for professional cyclists who have repeatedly violated the rules during races.

sen.j: 5日程度過酷な修行をし、自転車の練習も出来ないことから選手からは「お寺ゆき」として恐れられている。
sen.e: The athletes fear "going to the temple" as the 5 days of rigorous training leaves them unable to practice cycling.
The athletes fear 'going to the temple' as the 5 days of rigorous training leaves them unable to practice cycling.
The athletes fear 'going to the temple' as the 5 days of rigorous training leaves them unable to practice cycling.

sen.j: 西日本旅客鉄道奈良線・京阪電気鉄道京阪宇治線 黄檗駅下車、徒歩5分
sen.e: 5 minutes walk from Obaku station, which can be reached by the West Japan Railway Company Nara Line or the Keihan Electric Railway Co., Ltd. Keihan Uji Line.
sen.cmt: ・West Japan Railway Company Nara Line: http://www.westjr.co.jp/english/travel/jrp/index.html・Keihan Electric Railway Co., Ltd. Keihan Uji Line: http://www.keihan.co.jp/english_site/company.html
sen.e: 5 minutes walk from Obaku station, which can be reached by the West Japan Railway Company Nara Line or the Keihan Electric Railway Co., Ltd. Keihan Uji Line.
